explanation: to do or say something to make people feel relaxed, especially in social situations
to start doing something immediately and energetically, without waiting
to have the same understanding or knowledge about something

expression: put all your eggs in one basket
explanation: to risk everything on a single venture, instead of spreading the risk
to argue against an idea or viewpoint for the sake of debate or to explore its implications
to get to the important point without wasting time on unnecessary details

expression: hit the nail on the head
explanation: to describe exactly what is causing a situation or problem
to start something, especially an activity or a process, that creates momentum or progress
to work late into the night or early morning
to stop working on something for the rest of the day

expression: kick the can down the road
explanation: to postpone dealing with a problem or making a decision, often repeatedly
to think creatively and look at things in a new or different way
to have many different responsibilities or roles
to make a great effort to do something or to help someone
to learn how to do something or understand something

expression: at the drop of a hat
explanation: immediately and without any delay

expression: bite off more than you can chew
explanation: to try to do too much, or more than you can handle
to understand the situation or what someone is trying to say
to contribute or offer something of value or importance
to watch or take care of something or someone
to cost a lot of money, or to spend a lot of money
to ask someone for advice or information on a particular subject
to reveal a secret or disclose confidential information
to ignore something that you know about or that is happening

expression: cross that bridge when you come to it
explanation: to deal with a problem if and when it becomes necessary, not before
back to the beginning because an idea or plan failed
to get a rough estimate or approximate number
to be highly successful or to win a large prize or reward
to avoid responsibility by passing it on to someone else
to use personal influence or connections to achieve a goal
to spend as much money as necessary to achieve a particular goal

expression: take the bull by the horns
explanation: to confront a problem or difficult situation directly and with courage
to avoid talking about or addressing something directly
to be pursuing the wrong course of action or looking in the wrong place
to endure a painful or difficult situation with courage
to be in charge or make the decisions
to do something in the quickest, cheapest, or easiest way, often sacrificing quality
to have no chance of success or progress
to focus on the important or serious aspects of a situation
to give a brief summary or conclusion of a longer story or explanation
to handle a situation as it develops, without a clear plan
to make a good impression or to do something as well as possible
to irritate or annoy someone

expression: the ball is in your court
explanation: it is your responsibility to make a decision or take action
feeling ill or not in good health

expression: wear your heart on your sleeve
explanation: to be transparent or open about your emotions or feelings
to earn a living or provide financial support for a family
